Subsubsection Text: The following tables set forth our financial information as of the dates and for the periods indicated below. The Group financial information as of and for the 52 weeks ended March 31, 2018, the 52 weeks ended March 30, 2019 and the 52 weeks ended March 28, 2020 has been derived from the Audited Consolidated Group Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. These Audited Consolidated Group Financial Statements have been audited by Grant Thornton UK LLP and have been prepared in accordance with IFRS. Our Unaudited Group Interim Financial Statements included herein and the accompanying notes thereto as of and for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, including the comparative financial statements for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, have been prepared by the Group in accordance with the requirements of Rule 18 of the AIM Rules for Companies. We prepare our financial statements on the basis of a 52-week or 53-week financial period. Additionally, we prepare our half-year financial statements on the basis of 26-week or 27-week periods. Consequently, unless otherwise indicated, our results for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020 include an additional week of trading as compared to the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, which affects the comparability of our results of operations between periods. For the purposes of this Offering Memorandum, we refer to the 52 weeks ended March 28, 2020 as the ‘‘2020 financial year,’’ the 52 weeks ended March 30, 2019 as the ‘‘2019 financial year’’ and the 52 weeks ended March 31, 2018 as the ‘‘2018 financial year.’’ The following selected financial information should be read in conjunction with, and is qualified in its entirety by reference to, the Consolidated Group Financial Statements and other relevant information included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. You should also read the following information in conjunction with the ‘‘Presentation of Financial Information,’’ ‘‘Risk Factors,’’ ‘‘Capitalization,’’ ‘‘Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.’’

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading international designer, manufacturer and distributor of innovative flooring products across the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Australia, established in 1895 and publicly listed since 1963. In each of our product segments, we have leading market positions in the markets in which we operate. We are a leading Continental European ceramic tile manufacturer. In soft flooring, we are the largest carpet manufacturer in the United Kingdom, the second largest carpet manufacturer in Australia and the largest flooring underlay manufacturer in both countries, in each case by volume. We manufacture and supply a diversified range of products, including carpet, ceramic tiles, flooring underlay, luxury vinyl tile (‘‘LVT’’), artificial grass and flooring accessories. The majority of our products are for residential use, with a particular focus on the improvement and repair (‘‘I&R’’) end-market. We primarily target mid- to upper-market product segments of the flooring industry as well as certain niche product segments. Our customer base is diverse and focused on small, independent retailers with whom we can differentiate ourselves from competitors by offering superior service. We group our reported operating segments by product category and manufacturing geography. These segments, broadly divided into ceramic tile and soft flooring offerings, comprise: (i) UK & Europe— Ceramic Tiles, consisting of our ceramic tile manufacturing businesses in Spain and Italy; (ii) UK & Europe—Soft Flooring, consisting predominantly of our carpet, flooring underlay, artificial grass, LVT and flooring accessories businesses in the United Kingdom and Continental Europe; and (iii) Australia, consisting of our (predominantly carpet and flooring underlay) soft flooring businesses in Australia. In the 2020 financial year, ceramic tile accounted for 61.3% of our Underlying EBITDA, with soft flooring and other products accounting for the remaining 37.6% of our Underlying EBITDA (in both cases, excluding the impact of IFRS 16—Leases). For the 53 weeks ended October 3, 2020, we generated £673.5 million of _Pro Forma Revenue and £120.4 million of Pro Forma EBITDA (17.9% Pro Forma EBITDA margin). While we have grown largely through strategic acquisitions since 2013, like-for-like revenue growth was 1.6%, 2.0% and 0.4% for the 2018, 2019 and 2020 financial years, respectively. 58 ----- Our revenue and Underlying EBITDA is diversified across a variety of products and geographies. Through a series of strategic acquisitions, we have developed a balanced operating model across ceramic tiles and soft flooring, offering a diversified product portfolio of flooring products, both in terms of product category and target price point. Although originally focused on soft flooring offerings, we have gained scale in the large and fragmented flooring industry through a combination of acquisitions and organic initiatives to become a major competitor in both the soft and hard flooring markets. In particular, our Keraben, Serra, Saloni and Ibero businesses, together with our recent acquisitions of Ascot and Keradom, give us a market-leading position in the higher-margin Continental European ceramic tile business, while diversifying our product offering and geographic exposure. The following charts set forth our Underlying EBITDA by destination geography and product segment for the 2020 financial year (excluding the impact of IFRS 16—Leases). 20FEB202101404069 (1) Geographic split is based on Underlying EBITDA split by destination. (2) This split assumes a consistent margin on sales across all geographies and for each business unit. (3) Includes small amounts attributable to LVT and other products. We have gained scale in the large and fragmented flooring industry through a combination of acquisitions and organic initiatives to become a major competitor in both the soft and hard flooring markets. To build on the competitive advantage of our soft flooring capabilities, we expanded into the complementary flooring underlay market by adding flooring underlay operations in both the United Kingdom and Australia in 2015 and 2016, respectively. This was achieved through the acquisitions of Interfloor in 2015 and Ezi Floor in 2016, flooring underlay manufacturers based in the United Kingdom, and the 2016 acquisition of Dunlop, a flooring underlay manufacturer based in Australia. In response to robust growth in demand for artificial grass, we further expanded into the artificial grass market through our acquisitions of GrassInc and Avalon in the Netherlands in 2017. We entered the ceramic tile segment in Continental Europe through our acquisitions of Serra (Italy) and Keraben (Spain) in 2017, Saloni (Spain) in 2018, Ibero (Spain) in 2019 and Ascot (Italy) and Keradom (Italy) in 2020. These strategic acquisitions have given us a market-leading position in the higher-margin Continental European ceramic tile business, while diversifying our product offering and geographic footprint. In 2019, we also made the small acquisition of Estillon B.V., a small underlay distributor in Continental Europe, and further added to our soft flooring distribution offering in the United Kingdom with our acquisition of Hanover in January 2021. We believe we have achieved an optimal level of integration with respect to our recent strategic acquisitions, enabling us to develop a balanced operating model across ceramic and soft flooring, offering a diversified product portfolio of flooring products. We have a highly successful multi-brand strategy with over 30 brands encompassing mid- to upper-priced products. These include 14 carpet brands covering a broad range of wool and synthetic products, such as Victoria, Whitestone Weavers, StainFree and Quest; Westex and Hugh Mackay, two of our premium carpet brands; Duralay, Dunlop and Tredaire, leading and innovative flooring underlay brands; Keraben and Saloni, mid- to upper-market ceramic tile brands; Distinctive, Heartridge and Frontier, under which we sell high-end LVT products; and GrassInc and Avalon, under which we sell artificial grass products for a wide range of applications, including lawns, parks, sports grounds and indoor applications. We benefit from economies of scale through our consolidated manufacturing facilities in the United Kingdom, Spain, Italy and Australia. Our business is selectively vertically integrated, comprising three components: (i) the design and specification of the majority of our products; (ii) the manufacturing of the substantial majority of our products, with limited outsourcing in circumstances in which doing so is 59 20FEB202101404069 ----- financially and operationally beneficial; and (iii) the distribution of our products based on their product category and customer proposition, which maximizes the turnover of our inventory and product efficiency. We believe that this balanced approach to vertical integration creates robust margins and increases our competitive advantage in our target markets. We believe we have competitive advantages in the markets in which we operate, including our design capabilities, large-scale and efficient in-house manufacturing facilities and our long-standing direct relationships with retailers across all operating businesses. We operate fourteen manufacturing sites in the United Kingdom and Continental Europe and three manufacturing sites in Australia. Our integrated in-house capabilities allow us to operate our production facilities flexibly, varying production levels to meet demand, while maintaining a low fixed cost base, high efficiency and rigorous quality control. Where advantageous to do so, we have consolidated the design, manufacturing and distribution of certain products. Our core markets are the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Australia, where we employ over 3,400 people across more than 20 sites. The largest end-market for our products is the improvement and repair (‘‘I&R’’) end-market, and, therefore, our business is less exposed to the economic cycles that otherwise commonly affect the smaller, cyclical construction end-market. We sell the substantial majority of our products in the same geographical segments in which they are manufactured, placing us in close proximity to our customer bases across core markets. Our relationships with our customers, the thousands of flooring retailers and small number of distributors and direct sales customers we supply across the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Australia, are central to our success. We primarily sell directly to retailers. In the United Kingdom, our 3,000-plus customers range from independent retailers to distributors and large format chains. Some of these relationships, across operating geographies, are multigenerational and we believe the strength and depth of these relationships represent a significant competitive advantage. When coupled with our expansion since 2013, these relationships allow us to offer a broad range of products to our customers and further our cross-selling opportunities. We benefit from a large, diverse customer base with limited concentration. For the 2020 financial year, our top ten customers constituted approximately 18% of our revenue, with our largest customer constituting approximately 3% of our revenue.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We offer an extensive range of mid- to upper-market flooring products in a variety of designs across our hard and soft flooring product segments, which comprise ceramic tiles, carpet, underlay and accessories and LVT. As the margins on our products vary, changes in the mix of our product sales have a direct impact on our total revenue and profitability. We typically achieve higher margins on sales in our hard flooring segments, and, as a result, growth in these product segments relative to our soft flooring segments generally results in improved overall profitability. The margins in our hard flooring segment are typically higher than the margins in our soft flooring segment because, in Continental Europe and globally, demand for hard flooring products is high, with supply concentrated in small pockets of regional expertise. The fact that the design of hard flooring products tends to be more varied and intricate also contributes to their higher margins. In addition, the fact that our businesses are technologically well-invested has further contributed to our margins. In order to take advantage of the higher margins in the hard flooring segment, we expanded into the ceramic tile (a type of hard flooring product) market through our acquisitions of Serra and Keraben in 2017, Saloni in 2018, Ibero in 2019 and Ascot and Keradom in 2020. The resulting shift in our product mix has been a significant factor in increasing our Underlying EBITDA margin from 15.2% in the 2018 financial year to 18.3% in the 53 weeks ended October 3, 2020. 60 ----- The following charts set forth our 2020 Underlying EBITDA by destination geography and product segment. 20FEB202101404069 (1) Geographic split is based on Underlying EBITDA split by destination. (2) This split assumes a consistent margin on sales across all geographies and for each business unit. (3) Includes small amounts attributable to LVT and other products. Additionally, our range of products have varying margins in the different geographic regions in which we operate and, therefore, our geographic mix impacts our results of operation. Through our Keraben, Saloni, Serra and Ibero businesses, and our recent acquisitions of Ascot and Keradom, we have significant geographic diversity of sales. In the 2020 financial year, we sold our products in more than 20 countries globally. The United Kingdom, Australia, Spain and France are our largest markets, representing 40.8%, 14.0%, 15.0% and 7.8% of our revenue, respectively, for the 2020 financial year.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Based on the composition of our customer base, we believe that the substantial majority of our revenues are generated in the I&R end-market. We focus on the I&R end-market as it is five to six times larger than the new construction end-market in the United Kingdom and Continental Europe and also less cyclical. Consumer decisions regarding the redecoration and renovation of existing properties are therefore a major driver of our business. Our business is therefore affected by our ability to design and manufacture new and attractive products in line with consumer preferences as well as overall consumer demand in the I&R end-market. Consumers typically base their decision to purchase our products on a broad range of factors, including color, design, texture, shape, dimensions, pile height and density, price and other structural and technical features. In order to satisfy this broad range of preferences, we have built a portfolio of over 30 brands, have experienced design teams that are specific to these brands and have well-invested manufacturing equipment to support new product lines and adapt to shifts in demand. We aim to have optimal reach across the mid- and upper-market in our product segments, which allows us to deliver strong and sustainable margins. Demand for new flooring in the I&R end-market is typically less volatile than the new construction end-market. As the I&R end-market is driven by consistent wear-and-tear damage and the desire to upgrade the appearance of existing homes, this market is characterized by greater price inelasticity and less susceptibility to fluctuations in the business cycle. While impacted by macroeconomic factors such as GDP growth, the level of employment, real wage levels and consumer confidence, we believe that demand for flooring in the I&R end-market is, to a certain degree, less susceptible to short-term macroeconomic fluctuations, as consumers can decide to repair or upgrade their flooring independently of other home improvement decisions. Notably, in the 2020 financial year and in the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, we have benefited, and continue to benefit from increased global demand for home decoration and renovation materials from consumers who are spending increasing amounts of time at home as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Even in countries which have implemented stringent COVID-19 lockdown and quarantine measures, renovation activity has continued. We seek to follow consumer preferences and demand trends closely, using a systematic approach to collection planning, and maintaining a short design-to-product cycle. Our design, quality control, production and cost control processes are mutually reinforcing, resulting in product specifications that 61 20FEB202101404069 ----- align with our target customers and price points while ensuring optimal margins. We have the ability to set up our machines and re-engineer our production facilities, as well as increase our production capacity to manufacture new and different products in response to changing trends and consumer preferences. In addition, the breadth of our product offerings and our ability to redeploy our machines to make new designs makes us less subject to the success or failure of any given collection.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We are a manufacturer and therefore rely on well-invested production equipment, labor and raw materials to run our business. Of our cost of sales (excluding depreciation) in the 2020 financial year, materials (including other direct costs such as packaging) comprised 71.2%, labor comprised 18.2% and overhead comprised 10.6%. We are dependent on certain key raw materials, including synthetic yarn, wool, clay and polyurethane foam, and therefore our margins are impacted by variations in the cost of these raw materials. We manage the purchase of our key raw materials carefully, leveraging our scale and engaging with multiple suppliers in order to optimize pricing and security of supply. See ‘‘—Macroeconomic Factors—Raw Material _Expenses.’’_ Despite being a manufacturing business, we have a relatively low fixed cost base as a result of our automation of certain processes as well as the fact that our equipment generally has a very long useful life, given proper maintenance. We estimate that 52.3% of our cost base (which represents 43.3% of our revenues) for the 2020 financial year vary directly with revenue. A further 35.5% of our cost base (which represents 29.4% of our revenues) for the 2020 financial year is semi-variable, in respect of which we have the ability to adapt within a few months. In order to ensure that our manufacturing process is nimble and cost-effective, we are required to periodically make capital investments in our plant and equipment, which is further translated into depreciation on our income statement. Additionally, our business requires a limited amount of maintenance capital expenditures relative to our cash flows; of our capital expenditures for the 2020 financial year, £25.4 million related to maintenance (2019: £23.5, 2018: £14.1 million) and £8.4 million related to growth (2019: £20.9 million, 2018: £15.2 million). We spent £11.3 million on capital expenditures in the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, of which £9.1 million related to maintenance and £2.2 million related to growth. Further, following the acquisition of a new business, we look to realize operating cost synergies in order to drive margin enhancements. The purpose of these initiatives is to drive better buying terms with suppliers of raw materials, better working capital management through SKU reduction and rationalization of product lines and manufacturing assets. Realizing these operating synergies improves our margins by allowing us to manufacture our products more efficiently, including across a wide range of different SKUs, and allowing us to plan our production requirements in line with shifts in demand. We organize our operations so that we can flexibly shift production in line with changes to product specifications and to accommodate new designs. Through our acquisitions since 2013, we have significantly increased the scale of our operations in the United Kingdom and in the carpet segment, in particular. As a result of this increased scale, and to optimize our cost structure, we embarked on two restructuring initiatives in the United Kingdom: one with respect to manufacturing and one with respect to logistics. In 2017, we closed our Kidderminster factory, resulting in our UK carpet production now being shared between factories located in Yorkshire and South Wales. We recently completed a similar initiative in Australia, which has resulted in the consolidation of our two underlay factories into a single, enlarged facility. We have also completed the relocation of our Midlands Distribution Center and opened our Southern Distribution Center near London. We are still in the process of refining the multi-site operation of these distribution centers. The total cost of these projects incurred in the 2018 financial year was £4.5 million plus certain one-off capital expenditures equal to £3.3 million. In the 2020 financial year, we further increased our logistics capabilities through the in-sourcing of underlay delivery logistics, which has improved service levels and distribution flexibility, and additional investment in our logistics-focused subsidiary, Alliance Flooring Distribution. We have also begun construction on a new storage warehouse for finished carpet rolls in Wales to reduce the cost of volume shipments and reduce pressure on our other logistics centers located in England, which we expect will be completed in March 2021. The total cost of these projects incurred in the 2020 financial year was £2.2 million. 62 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We generally operate a business-to-business sales model and therefore rarely access the end-consumer directly. Therefore we rely on our customers’ ability to sell and market our products effectively in order to increase our revenue and generate sustainable cash flows. As our customers grow, they tend also to increase their orders with us. We thus seek to maintain strong relationships with our customers and work side-by-side with them to help increase store traffic and grow their business. We predominantly focus on selling directly to retailers, which represented 66.6% of Group revenue for the 2020 financial year. Approximately two-thirds of our direct sales to retailers are made to specialist retailers, with the rest going to either national retail chains or DIY retailers. We also sell certain of our products in certain jurisdictions to wholesalers where there is a structural or commercial rationale for doing so, and engage in a small amount of contract work for the construction or hospitality industry representing 1.0% of Group revenue for the 2020 financial year. We have developed what we believe are deep, longstanding relationships with our customers. We benefit from a broad range of customers with little concentration. The diversity of our customers across geographies means that we have been able to maintain relatively stable sales notwithstanding government-mandated lockdowns and restrictions in any single country (we estimate that, as of March 28, 2020, we generated approximately 60% of our revenues from outside of the United Kingdom). Notwithstanding the COVID-19 pandemic, we have not experienced materially decreased demand from our top ten customers in the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, as compared to the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. For the 2020 financial year, our top ten customers constituted approximately 18% of total revenue, with our largest customer constituting approximately 3% of total revenue. In addition to ensuring low customer concentration, this diverse network of independent retailer customers presents a significant barrier to entry for new market participants.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: _General Economic Conditions and Industry Environment_ Our results of operations are affected by macroeconomic conditions, as well as the conditions affecting consumer spending on flooring in the markets in which we operate. Such conditions include levels of employment, consumer confidence, inflation, growth in GDP, real disposable income, currency exchange rates, interest rates, home prices and the availability of consumer credit. Additionally, the COVID-19 pandemic continues to affect global macroeconomic conditions, impacting global consumer confidence and GDP growth. All of the markets in which we operate have been adversely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Nevertheless, we believe our prior experience and success in dealing with major economic downturns has left us well-positioned to deal with the economic effects of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The Group was resilient throughout the 2008 financial crisis, increasing revenue in each year of the 2006-2011 financial period. While we shifted our sales mix to lower than average selling prices to protect sales volumes, we were able to utilize our flexible cost base to protect our margins. As macroeconomic indicators like GDP, real wages and employment levels improved across the United Kingdom, Continental Europe and Australia subsequent to the global financial crisis, we saw an increase in the rate of growth in the flooring market, and we believe that a similar increase is possible once the health consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic are brought under control and macroeconomic conditions stabilize. Overall economic conditions typically have a direct impact on the specific markets that drive our business, although market sensitivity varies, depending on the product. Our business is focused on the I&R end-market, which is less susceptible to the effects of an economic downturn than the new construction end-market, which typically fluctuates in line with the overall business cycle. Additionally, we target the mid- and upper-markets of the flooring market, which have historically been more resilient during economic downturns. During an economic downturn, raw material prices typically decrease, which can mitigate the adverse effect of potential volume decreases. We also believe that our strategic goal of expanding our presence in Continental Europe and Australia have increased our geographic and product diversification, and thereby allow us to further mitigate the impact of changes in local and regional economic conditions and consumer preferences. For example, uncertainty around the United Kingdom and Eurozone economic outlooks, driven by the exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union, is mitigated by the operational independence of our United Kingdom and Continental European divisions and the fact that neither is heavily reliant on imports or exports. See ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Industry and Our Business— 63 ----- _The United Kingdom’s withdrawal from the European Union (‘‘Brexit’’) may have a negative effect on global or regional economic conditions, financial markets and our business, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.’’ Foreign Exchange Rate Fluctuations_ We operate internationally and, as a result, are exposed to changes in the value of our operational currencies, the pound sterling, the euro, the Australian dollar and the U.S. dollar. For the 2020 financial year, 40.6% of our revenue was denominated in pound sterling, 15.3% of our revenue was denominated in Australian dollars, and 44.1% of our revenue was denominated in euro. As a consequence, we have considerable cash flow, earnings and assets in currencies other than our reporting currency, which is the pound sterling. Our exposure to changes in exchange rates may be described in terms of translation exposure and transaction exposure. See ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Industry and Our Business— _Our operations require the use of several different currencies, exposing us to both transaction and translation effects of exchange rate fluctuations that could adversely affect our profitability, costs and ability to repay indebtedness or comply with certain maintenance covenants.’’_ Translation risk is the risk that exchange rates impact the value of our revenues, costs, assets and liabilities reported in pounds sterling in our Consolidated Financial Statements. The weakening of the pound sterling relative to our other operational currencies will result in an increase in our revenues and costs as reported in pounds sterling. For example, since the national referendum in the United Kingdom on Brexit in June 2016, the value of the pound sterling relative our other operational currencies has declined, resulting in an increase in our reported revenues and costs. In addition, the majority of our debt is, and will continue to be following the Offering, denominated in euro and therefore the amount of our reported indebtedness is subject to a certain degree of currencyrelated fluctuations when translated into pounds sterling for inclusion in our financial statements at period-end exchange rates. Transaction risk arises when our subsidiaries execute transactions in a currency other than their functional currency. As a result of our operational structure, our exposure to currency transaction risk is relatively limited, with approximately 83% of our costs denominated in the relevant local operating currency in the 2020 financial year. Our primary transactional risk exposure comes in the form of raw material purchases by our United Kingdom and Australian operations, in which sales are predominantly denominated in pounds sterling and Australian dollars, respectively, but which have costs denominated in euro and U.S. dollars (approximately 4% and 13% for the 2020 financial year, respectively). Our Continental European ceramic tile businesses have very little transactional risk exposure. We mitigate our limited transactional risk through forward exchange contracts up to 12 months in advance to hedge our residual exposure to currencies other than the pound sterling. See ‘‘—Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosure About Market _Risk—Currency Risk.’’_ Fluctuations in the value of the euro and Australian dollar relative to the pound sterling typically have a short-term impact on our gross margin as, on the revenue side, both we and our customers seek to adjust prices in response to foreign currency fluctuations. On the expense side, both we and our suppliers also seek to adjust prices. In addition, our industry is competitive and elastic, as demonstrated by price rebalancing across the industry in response to foreign currency and raw material price fluctuations. Changes in foreign exchange rates also have an impact on the competitive dynamics within our markets, in particular with respect to our UK carpet business. As the majority of carpeting in the United Kingdom is imported from competitors in Continental Europe, the weakening of the pound sterling relative to the euro increases our competitive advantage in this market. See ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Industry _and Business—Our operations require the use of several different currencies, exposing us to both transaction and translation effects of exchange rate fluctuations that could adversely affect our profitability, costs and ability to repay indebtedness or comply with certain maintenance covenants.’’_ The effect of a 10% strengthening of the euro against the pound sterling over the full year would, all other variables held constant, have resulted in an increase in Group post-tax loss for the 2020 financial year of £47.7 million. A 10% weakening in the euro against the pound sterling would, on the same basis, have decreased Group post-tax loss by £39.0 million. 64 ----- _Raw Materials Expenses_ Raw materials constitute the majority of our production costs. Our key raw material inputs for the 2020 financial year (other than electricity at approximately 1% of costs) were: (i) with respect to carpets, synthetic yarn (approximately 29% of costs); (ii) with respect to ceramics, clay and natural gas (approximately 14% and 9% of costs, respectively); and (iii) with respect to underlay, polyurethane foam trim (approximately 22% of costs). As supply for these inputs is relatively unconstrained, our underlying raw material expenses do not typically exhibit significant volatility. In any event, we seek to pass-through any increases in raw material prices to our customers. Additionally, we have a broad range of suppliers, with our top ten suppliers approximately constituting only 19% of our total expenditure with third parties for the 2020 financial year. In some instances, prices are fixed pursuant to long-term agreements but, more commonly, the Group purchases strategically using competitive processes. We typically review prices every six to 12 months. The primary source of volatility with respect to our raw material expenses is currency risk, primarily with respect to synthetic yarn and polyurethane foam trim, which we purchase in euro and U.S. dollars. We significantly mitigate this risk through forward exchange contracts to hedge our residual exposure to currencies other than the pound sterling. We have not experienced any material price increases or disruptions to our supply of key raw material inputs as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. See ‘‘—Foreign Exchange Rate Fluctuations.’’

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our acquisition strategy is primarily focused on our targets as stand-alone propositions. We seek to acquire businesses that are growing and profitable, with high-quality facilities and products as well as competitive advantages in production and distribution. In line with our commitment to sustainable growth, we look to a combination of equity and debt funding to acquire material businesses and to maintain leverage levels in line with our historical performance and financial policy. In November 2017, the Group acquired the entire share capital of Keraben for total consideration of A274.1 million (£243.4 million). Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1258 = £1.00, which was the exchange rate as of the date of the acquisition. Keraben, which is based in Castell´on, Spain, designs, manufactures and distributes a range of mid- to upper-market white body and porcelain tiles for both wall and floor covering. The enlarged group, containing three brands with strong market reputation, is substantially diversified in terms of both product and geography and is an ideal platform for further potential acquisitions in the ceramic tile segment. The Group results for the 2018 financial year included contribution from Keraben of A46.8 million (£41.1 million) of revenue and A10.8 million (£9.5 million) of profit before tax (before amortization of acquired intangibles and acquisition costs). Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1373 = £1.00, which was the period average for the 2018 financial year. Keraben’s results have been consolidated with our own from the date of its acquisition in November 2017. In December 2017, the Group acquired the entire share capital of Serra for initial cash consideration of A38.1 million (£33.6 million) and deferred cash consideration of up to A20.0 million (£17.7 million) payable over the next four succeeding years. Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1341 = £1.00, which was the exchange rate as of the date of the acquisition. Serra, which is based in Serramazzoni, Italy, sells and exports ceramic tiles domestically and abroad, selling to a combination of wholesalers, retail groups and independent stores throughout Continental Europe, North America and Asia. The Group results for the 2018 financial year included contribution from Serra of A6.5 million (£5.7 million) of revenue and A2.5 million (£2.2 million) of profit before tax (before amortization of acquired intangibles and acquisition costs). Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1373 = £1.00, which was the period average for the 2018 financial year. Serra’s results have been consolidated with our own from the date of its acquisition in December 2017. In August 2018, the Group acquired the entire share capital of Saloni, a Spanish ceramic tile business based in Castell´on, Spain, from Obinesa Grupo Industrial S.L. for cash consideration of A96.7 million (£86.2 million). Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1218 = £1.00, which was the exchange rate as of the date of the acquisition. The acquisition further drives our expansion in the Continental European ceramic tile segment and presents opportunities for synergies with our existing businesses. The Group results for the 2019 financial year included contribution from Saloni of A65.2 million (£57.5 million) of revenue and A5.8 million (£5.1 million) of profit before tax. Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1344 = £1.00, which was the period average 65 ----- for the 2019 financial year. Saloni’s results have been consolidated with our own from the date of its acquisition in August 2018. In August 2019, the Group acquired the business and certain assets of Iberoalcorense, S.L.U., a Spanish ceramic tile business based in Castell´on, Spain, selling domestically and internationally to a combination of wholesalers, retail groups and independent stores throughout Continental Europe, North America and the Middle East. The Group paid initial cash consideration of A9.4 million (£8.6 million), and deferred and contingent consideration of up to A6.2 million (£5.7 million), subject to further post-closing adjustments. Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.0864 = £1.00, which was the exchange rate as of the date of the acquisition. The acquisition continues our expansion in the Continental European ceramic tile segment and presents opportunities for synergies with our existing Keraben and Saloni businesses. The Group results for the 2020 financial year included contribution from Ibero of A15.3 million of revenue (£13.3 million) of revenue and A0.6 million (£0.5 million) of profit before tax (before amortization of acquired intangibles and acquisition costs). Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1324 = £1.00, which was the period average for the 2019 financial year. Ibero’s results have been consolidated with our own from the date of its acquisition in August 2019. In November 2019, the Group acquired the entire share capital of a small underlay distributor in Continental Europe, Estillon B.V., for a total purchase price of A5.7 million (£5.0 million) consisting of initial cash consideration of A3.2 million (£2.8 million) (the remainder comprising deferred and contingent consideration). Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1593 = £1.00, which was the exchange rate as of the date of the acquisition. The Group results for the 2020 financial year included contribution from Estillon of A4.8 million of revenue (£4.2 million) of revenue and A0.3 million (£0.3 million) of Underlying EBITDA. Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1442 = £1.00, which was the period average for the 2020 financial year. Estillon’s results have been consolidated with our own from the date of its acquisition in November 2019. In March 2020, the Group entered into an agreement to lease (with the option to purchase) the entire business and manufacturing facilities of Ascot Gruppo Ceramiche S.r.l., a manufacturer of high-quality porcelain ceramic flooring in Sassuolo, Italy selling domestically and internationally to a combination of wholesalers, retail groups and independent stores throughout Continental Europe. Total consideration for the lease and accompanying option amounted to A11.5 million (£9.9 million), all of which was deferred on completion, with payments being made over the period of the seven year lease (in annual instalments) up to the point at which the option to acquire is exercised (at no additional cost), at which time the balance of the total consideration is due. The transaction further drives our expansion in the Continental European ceramic tile segment and presents opportunities for synergies with our existing Serra business. The Group maintains full control over Ascot and intends to exercise the acquisition option. The Group results for the 2020 financial year included contribution from Ascot of A4.8 million (£4.2 million) of revenue and A0.4 million (£0.3 million) of profit before tax (before amortization of acquired intangibles and acquisition costs). Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1442 = £1.00, which was the period average for the 2020 financial year. Ascot’s results have been consolidated with our own from the date of its acquisition in March 2020. In December 2020, the Group acquired the entire share capital of Keradom S.r.l., an Italian manufacturer of high-quality porcelain ceramic flooring in Sassuolo, Italy, consisting of initial cash consideration of A4.6 million (£4.1 million), and deferred and contingent consideration of up to A8.0 million (£7.2 million), subject to potential further performance-based post-closing adjustments. Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1103 = £1.00, which was the exchange rate as of the date of the acquisition. The transaction further drives our expansion in the Continental European ceramic tile segment and presents opportunities for synergies with our existing Italian businesses. Pro forma for the acquisition, the Group results for the 53 weeks ended October 3, 2020 would have included contribution from Keradom of A21.1 million (£18.4 million) of revenue and A3.5 million (£3.1 million) of Underlying EBITDA. Euro amounts have been converted into pounds sterling at a rate equal to A1.1442 = £1.00, which was the period average for the 2020 financial year. Keradom’s results have been consolidated with our own from the date of its acquisition in December 2020. In January 2021, the Group acquired the business and certain assets of an English distributor of soft flooring products, Hanover Flooring Limited, for initial cash consideration of £1.0 million, deferred consideration of £12.5 million and contingent consideration of up to £11.5 million, each subject to potential further post-closing adjustments. The transaction further drives our distribution capabilities in the United Kingdom and presents opportunities for synergies with our existing businesses in the United 66 ----- Kingdom. Pro forma for the acquisition, the Group results for the 53 weeks ended October 3, 2020 would have included contribution from Hanover of £16.1 million of revenue and £3.1 million of Underlying EBITDA.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our carpet and underlay sales in the United Kingdom and Australia have historically been slightly higher in September, October and November, driven by an increase in home improvement activity in advance of the holiday season. Our ceramic tile sales in Continental Europe are less susceptible to seasonal variation, with August, December and January being our slow months as home improvement activity tapers off during and following holidays. Sales of artificial grass are the most susceptible to seasonal variation, with demand being highest between April and August in Continental Europe and the United Kingdom. Our working capital is highest just prior to the seasonal peak; given the lack of seasonal variation in our ceramic tile segment and the small scale of our artificial grass segment, this means our working capital tends to be at its highest in September and October of each year.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations, financial condition and liquidity have been influenced in the periods discussed in this Offering Memorandum by the following events, facts, developments and market characteristics. We believe that these factors are likely to continue to influence our operations in the future.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Results
Subsubsection Text: We prepare our financial statements on the basis of a 52-week or 53-week financial period. Additionally, we prepare our half-year financial statements on the basis of 26-week or 27-week periods. Consequently, unless otherwise indicated, our results for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020 include an additional week of trading as compared to the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, which affects the comparability of our results of operations between periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Results
Subsubsection Text: Our current operating segments are (i) UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles, (ii) UK & Europe—Soft Flooring and (iii) Australia. Prior to the 2019 financial year, we presented our soft flooring and hard flooring operating businesses in the United Kingdom and Continental Europe as a single operating segment (‘‘UK & Europe’’). We believe our current operating segments for those geographies, UK & Europe— Ceramic Tiles and UK & Europe—Soft Flooring, better present our operating results given our significant operations in both soft and hard flooring. To facilitate comparability of our operating segments, we have re-presented certain financial information presented for the 2018 financial year in the below section entitled ‘‘—Results of Operations—Comparison of results of operations for the 52 weeks ended March 31, 2018 _and the 52 weeks ended March 30, 2019—Revenue by operating segment’’ to give effect to our 2019 financial_ year re-segmentation. See ‘‘Definitions—UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles’’ and ‘‘Definitions—UK & Europe— _Soft Flooring.’’_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic and measures to prevent its spread, including the imposition of quarantines and any prolonged closures of our customers’ businesses, or the businesses of the third parties on which we rely, may impact us in a number of ways. This may include an adverse effect from reduced global economic activity, consumer confidence or disruptions in global supply chains, and, therefore, the products we manufacture, as well as the ability to operate our business, including potential disruptions to our supply chain and workforce. We expect the ultimate significance of the impact of these disruptions, including the extent of their adverse impact on financial and operational results, will be determined by the length of time that such disruptions continue which will, in turn, depend on the duration of the COVID-19 pandemic and the impact of governmental regulations that might be imposed in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. See ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Industry and Our Business—We face risks _related to health epidemics, pandemics and other outbreaks, including the COVID-19 pandemic, which could adversely affect our business.’’_ Nevertheless, we believe we have demonstrated continued resilience in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. We currently continue to operate all of our manufacturing facilities globally, and did not experience material price increases or disruptions to our supply of raw materials. We have maintained a robust liquidity position since the initial government-mandated lockdowns in March 2020 and have not accessed any government credit-line schemes. We have also been encouraged by our most recent results, as 67 ----- the initial drop in demand we experienced during the initial government-mandated lockdowns rebounded quickly and was followed by strong sales in the months of October, November and December, 2020. For more information, see ‘‘Summary—Recent _Developments—Recent_ _Trading,’’_ ‘‘Summary—Recent _Developments—COVID-19’’ and ‘‘—Results of Operations—Comparison of results of operations for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019 and the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020.’’_

Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Revenue is measured by reference to the fair value of consideration receivable by the Group for goods supplied, excluding VAT and trade discounts. Revenue is recognized upon the sale of goods or transfer of risk to the customer sold.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales represents variable expenses (excluding VAT and trade discounts) incurred from revenue generating activity, including cost of materials and production costs, labor costs and depreciation from the manufacture of goods.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Distribution costs include the cost of warehousing (including labor), internal transportation costs (including labor) and the cost of using third-party logistics providers.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Administrative expenses represents design and development costs, sales and marketing costs, operating lease rentals, losses on disposal of fixed assets, professional fees, salaries, information technology, human resources and other administrative costs.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Other operating income includes income from renting portions of our properties, sale of excess stock to auction houses, government grants and the generation and sale to the local power grid of electricity generated through Keraben’s manufacturing process.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation represents the depreciation of property, plant and equipment. Amortization represents the amortization of intangible assets, including the amortization of capitalized development costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Exceptional items are operating costs which are material by virtue of their size or incidence but are not expected to be recurring.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Non-underlying items are material non-trading costs and non-underlying finance costs as determined by the Board. They are disclosed separately in the Consolidated Group Financial Statements in order to fairly present the results for the period. Non-underlying items include the amortization of acquired intangibles, the release of prepaid arrangement fees on refinanced bank facilities, mark-to-market adjustments on foreign exchange contracts and interest rate swaps, deferred and contingent consideration fair value adjustments, share based payment charges and retranslation of foreign currency loans. For more information, see the ‘‘Significant Accounting Policies’’ section in the 2020 Group Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Finance (costs) / income are comprised of interest payable on loans, amortization of prepaid finance costs, interest accrued on the BGF Loan, interest charges on right-of-use leases, net interest expense on defined benefit pensions, fair value adjustments to redemption options on certain indebtedness, translation differences on foreign currency indebtedness and other non-underlying finance costs. 68 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: Taxation is comprised of the current year’s underlying current and deferred tax charge. The standard rate of tax applied to our underlying profit was 22.5% in the 2018 financial year, 24.3% in the 2019 financial year and 25.8% in the 2020 financial year.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Components of Our Income Statement
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, we have included references to certain Non-IFRS Measures, including Underlying EBITDA and Underlying EBITDA margin. We define Underlying EBITDA as earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, amortization and exceptional items. We define Underlying EBITDA margin as Underlying EBITDA divided by revenue. These Non-IFRS Measures are included in this Offering Memorandum because management believes they are useful to investors, securities analysts and other interested parties as additional measures of performance. These Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered in isolation and should not be considered as an alternative to profit or loss for the period or any other performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS. See ‘‘Presentation of Financial Information—Non-IFRS Measures’’ and ‘‘Summary _Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Data.’’_ See ‘‘Forward-Looking Statements’’ and ‘‘Risk Factors’’ for a discussion of certain factors that could affect our future performance and results of operation.

Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . (200.2) (203.2) _By operating segment:_ UK & Europe—Soft Flooring . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 144.2 126.0 UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 122.0 132.5 Australia . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 49.7 47.0 UK & Europe—Soft Flooring: Our revenue from UK & Europe—Soft Flooring segment decreased by £18.2 million, or 12.6%, to £126.0 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, from £144.2 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles: Our revenue from our UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles segment increased by £10.5 million, or 8.6%, to £132.5 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from £122.0 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. Australia: Our revenue from Australia decreased by £2.7 million, or 5.4%, to £47.0 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from £49.7 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. 70 ----- _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by £3.0 million, or 1.5%, to £203.2 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from £200.2 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. Our cost of sales increased primarily due to the full-period effect of our prior-period acquisition of Ibero, our acquisition of Ascot and the additional week of trading in the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020 as compared to the prior period. Our cost of sales as a percentage of total revenue increased by 3.1 percentage points from 63.4% for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, to 66.5% for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020. _Gross profit_ Gross profit decreased by £13.4 million, or 11.6%, to £102.3 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from £115.7 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. Our gross profit margin decreased by 3.1 percentage points from 36.6% for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, to 33.5% for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020. This was due to the full-period effect of our prior-period acquisition of Ibero, our acquisition of Ascot and the additional week of trading in the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020 as compared to the prior period. _Underlying administrative expenses and distribution costs_ Administrative expenses (excluding non-underlying and exceptional items) increased by £0.4 million, or 1.0%, to £39.6 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from £39.2 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, primarily due to the full-period effect of our prior-period acquisition of Ibero, our acquisition of Ascot and the additional week of trading in the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020 as compared to the prior period. Distribution costs decreased by £2.3 million, or 6.0%, to £36.0 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from £38.3 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, primarily due to lower sales activity during the period, our acquisition of Ascot and the additional week of trading in the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020 as compared to the prior period, partially off-set by lower distribution activity in the beginning of the period. In total, underlying administrative expenses and distribution costs for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, have, as a percentage of revenue, increased slightly at 24.7% of revenue, as compared to 24.5% of revenue for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. _Other operating income_ Other operating income remained flat at £1.5 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, as compared to £1.5 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. This income primarily relates to the sale to the local power grid of electricity generated as a byproduct of the manufacturing process from Keraben’s combined heat and power plant. _Underlying operating profit_ Underlying operating profit decreased by £11.5 million, or 29.0%, to £28.2 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from £39.7 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. This decrease is primarily attributable to decreased revenues and increased cost of sales for the period. Our underlying operating profit margin decreased by 3.5 percentage points from 12.7% for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, to 9.2% for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020. For further information on our like-for-like performance, see ‘‘—Results of Operations—Comparison of results of operations for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019 _and the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020—Underlying EBITDA.’’ Finance costs_ Our underlying finance costs increased by £2.3 million to £14.5 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from £12.2 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. This increase primarily reflects the additional interest costs resulting from the Existing Notes and an increase of £0.6 million in amounts related to the unwinding of the discount on right-of-use lease liabilities. Reported net finance costs decreased by £4.6 million to £13.7 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from £18.3 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, predominantly as a result of the absence of released prepaid finance costs as compared to the prior period and lack of underwriting fees and costs relating to bank facilities incurred in the prior period. 71 ----- _Taxation_ The reported corporation tax charge decreased by £2.4 million to a tax credit of £0.8 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from a tax charge of £1.6 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. The underlying tax charge of £3.5 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, when measured against underlying profit before tax, represents an effective tax rate of 25.5%. This compares to an underlying tax charge of £6.7 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, and an effective tax rate of 24.4%. The increase in the effective tax rate primarily reflects a greater contribution from subsidiaries in geographies where the corporate tax rate is higher than the historical Group effective tax rate, as a result the full-period impact of our acquisition of Ibero, which is located in Spain with an applicable local corporation tax rate of 25.0%, and our acquisition of Ascot, which is located in Italy with an applicable local corporation tax rate of 27.9%. _Underlying EBITDA_ Underlying EBITDA decreased by £6.1 million, or 10.4%, to £52.4 million for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, from £58.5 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to the challenging trading environment resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic and related government-imposed lockdowns across the geographies in which we operate. Nevertheless, we believe our record results in the post-lockdown period reflect significant pent-up and consistent demand. Our Underlying EBITDA margin decreased by 1.5 percentage points from 18.7% for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, to 17.2% for the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, which is attributable to the foregoing, notwithstanding an Underlying EBITDA margin of 20.1% in the post-lockdown period from June to September 2020. For the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, we generated Underlying EBITDA of £19.2 million in our UK & Europe—Soft Flooring segment, £27.7 million in our UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles segment and £6.2 million in Australia, as compared to £19.4 million, £34.4 million and £5.6 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, respectively. On a like-for-like basis and as compared to the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, our Underlying EBITDA margin: (i) increased by 150 basis points for our UK & Europe—Soft Flooring segment (an increase of 500 basis points in the post-lockdown period from June to September 2020 as compared to the equivalent prior-year period); (ii) decreased by 350 basis points for our UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles segment (an increase of 150 basis points in the post-lockdown period from June to September 2020 as compared to the equivalent prior-year period); and (iii) increased by 210 basis points in Australia (an increase of 260 basis points in the post-lockdown period from June to September 2020 as compared to the equivalent prior-year period). 72 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ During the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, our revenue decreased by £10.4 million, or 3.3%, to £305.5 million from £315.9 million for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019. The decrease in revenue was primarily due to a decrease in revenues attributable to our UK & Europe—Soft Flooring segment, partially offset by an increase in revenue generated by our UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles segment, with our Australia segment revenues decreasing slightly. From the months of June to September of 2020, however, our revenue increased by 9.2% on a like-for-like basis, which was primarily attributable to pent-up customer demand for our products following the cessation of government-mandated lockdowns in the summer of 2020. Our revenue from our UK & Europe—Soft Flooring segment decreased by 12.6% over this period, primarily due to the challenging trading environment resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic and related government-imposed lockdowns in the United Kingdom which spanned from the months of March to May of 2020. Revenues, however, in the post-lockdown period from June to September were 27.8% higher than revenues in the prior equivalent period (a like-for-like increase of 21.2% as compared to the equivalent prior-year period), supporting segment results and reflecting significant pent-up and consistent demand post-lockdown. Our revenue from our UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles segment increased by 8.6% over this period, primarily attributable to the full-period effect of our prior-period acquisition of Ibero and our acquisition of Ascot, supported by organic sales growth in post-lockdown revenues from June to September which were 27.4% higher than revenues in the equivalent prior-year period (a like-for-like decrease of 2.6% as compared to the equivalent prior-year period), reflecting significant pent-up and consistent demand post-lockdown. Our revenue from our Australia segment decreased by 5.4% over this period notwithstanding like-for-like revenue growth of 14.7% for the post-lockdown period from June to August as compared to the equivalent prior-year period, primarily due to the continued challenging trading environment, further impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and related government-imposed lockdowns in August and September 2020. _Revenue by operating segment_ The following table sets forth our revenue for the 26 weeks ended September 28, 2019, and the 27 weeks ended October 3, 2020, by operating segment.

(364.8) (395.1) _By operating segment:_ UK & Europe—Soft Flooring . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 272.9 282.0 UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 193.9 243.9 Australia . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 100.0 95.6 UK & Europe—Soft Flooring: Our revenue from UK & Europe—Soft Flooring segment increased by £9.1 million, or 3.3%, to £282.0 million for the 2020 financial year from £272.9 million for the 2019 financial year. UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles: Our revenue from our UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles segment increased by £50.0 million, or 25.8%, to £243.9 million for the 2020 financial year from £193.9 million for the 2019 financial year. Australia: Our revenue from Australia decreased by £4.4 million, or 4.4%, to £95.6 million for the 2020 financial year from £100.0 million for the 2019 financial year. _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by £30.3 million, or 8.3%, to £395.1 million for the 2020 financial year from £364.8 million for the 2019 financial year. Our cost of sales increased primarily due to the full-year effect of our prior-year acquisition of Saloni, our acquisitions of Ibero and Ascot and organic sales growth. Our cost of sales as a percentage of total revenue decreased by 0.8 percentage points from 64.4% for the 2019 financial year to 63.6% for the 2020 financial year. _Gross profit_ Gross profit increased by £24.4 million, or 12.1%, to £226.4 million for the 2020 financial year from £202.0 million for the 2019 financial year. Our gross profit margin increased by 0.8 percentage points from 35.6% for the 2019 financial year to 36.4% for the 2020 financial year. This was due to the full-year effect of our prior-year acquisition of Saloni, our acquisitions of Ibero and Ascot and organic sales growth. _Underlying administrative expenses and distribution costs_ Administrative expenses (excluding non-underlying and exceptional items) increased by £17.2 million, or 26.2%, to £82.9 million for the 2020 financial year from £65.7 million for the 2019 financial year. Distribution costs increased by £4.0 million, or 5.8%, to £73.2 million for the 2020 financial year from £69.2 million for the 2019 financial year. These increases were primarily due to the full-year effect of our prior-year acquisition of Saloni and our acquisitions of Ibero and Ascot. In total, underlying administrative expenses and distribution costs for the 2020 financial year have, as a percentage of revenue, remained relatively consistent at 25.1% of revenue, as compared to 23.8% of revenue in the 2019 financial year. _Other operating income_ Other operating income increased by £0.9 million, or 29.0%, to £4.0 million for the 2020 financial year from £3.1 million for the 2019 financial year. This income primarily relates to the sale to the local power 74 ----- grid of electricity generated as a byproduct of the manufacturing process from Keraben’s combined heat and power plant. _Underlying operating profit_ Underlying operating profit increased by £4.1 million, or 5.8%, to £74.3 million for the 2020 financial year from £70.2 million for the 2019 financial year. Our underlying operating profit margin decreased by 0.4 percentage points from 12.4% for the 2019 financial year to 12.0% for the 2020 financial year. This increase is primarily attributable to the full-year effect of our prior-year acquisition of Saloni and our acquisitions of Ibero and Ascot. _Finance costs_ Our underlying finance costs increased by £13.2 million, or 100.8%, to £26.3 million for the 2020 financial year from £13.1 million for the 2019 financial year. This primarily reflects the additional interest costs resulting from the Existing Notes. Reported net finance costs increased by £29.8 million, or 107.8%, to £57.5 million for the 2020 financial year from £27.7 million for the 2019 financial year, predominantly as a result of fair value adjustments to redemption options on the Existing Notes of £7.3 million, translation differences on foreign currency indebtedness of £13.0 million and £2.6 million related to the unwinding of the discount on right-of-use lease liabilities. _Taxation_ The reported corporation tax charge remained unchanged at £4.2 million for the 2020 financial year as compared to £4.2 million for the 2019 financial year. The underlying tax charge of £12.4 million for the 2020 financial year, when measured against underlying profit before tax, represents an effective tax rate of 25.8%. This compares to an underlying tax charge of £13.9 million for the 2019 financial year and an effective tax rate of 24.3%. The increase in the effective tax rate primarily reflects a greater contribution from subsidiaries in geographies where the corporate tax rate is higher than the historical Group effective tax rate, as a result of the full-year effect of our prior-year acquisition of Saloni and our acquisitions of Ibero and Ascot. _Underlying EBITDA_ Underlying EBITDA increased by £22.0 million, or 22.9%, to £118.1 million for the 2020 financial year from £96.1 million for the 2019 financial year. This increase was primarily due to the full-year effect of our prior-year acquisition of Saloni and our acquisitions of Ibero and Ascot. Our Underlying EBITDA margin increased by 2.0 percentage points from 17.0% for the 2019 financial year to 19.0% for the 2020 financial year, which is partially attributable to the shift in our product mix towards ceramic tile products. 75 -----

Subsubsection Text: (1) Our audited consolidated financial information for the 52 weeks ended March 30, 2019 was prepared on a pre-IFRS 16—Leases basis, while subsequent periods have been prepared on a post-IFRS 16—Leases basis. Accordingly, our audit consolidated financial information for the 52 weeks ended March 30, 2019 may not be comparable to results in subsequent periods. See the Significant Accounting Policies to our Consolidated Group Financial Statements. (2) As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, potential future credit risk across key customer categories was reassessed as at March 28, 2020, resulting in an increase in credit loss provision of £2.8 million. See Note 14 to the 2020 Group Financial Statements. _Revenue_ During the 2020 financial year, our revenue increased by £54.7 million, or 9.7%, to £621.5 million from £566.8 million for the 2019 financial year. The increase in revenue was primarily due to the full-year effect of our prior-year acquisition of Saloni, our acquisitions of Ibero and Ascot and organic sales growth. 73 ----- During the 2020 financial year, our revenue increased by 0.4% on a like-for-like basis, which was primarily attributable to like-for-like revenue growth in our UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles segments, partially offset by a decline in by our Australia segment. Our revenue from our UK & Europe—Soft Flooring segment remained flat on a like-for-like basis over this period. Our revenue from our Australia segment decreased by 1.0% on a like-for-like basis over this period, which was primarily due to the continued challenging trading environment. Our revenue from our UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles segment increased by 2.3% on a like-for-like basis over this period, which was primarily due to strong performance in the DIY retail segment in Continental Europe. _Revenue by operating segment_ The following table sets forth our revenue for the 2019 and 2020 financial years by operating segment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ During the 2019 financial year, our revenue increased by £142.0 million, or 33.4%, to £566.8 million from £424.8 million for the 2018 financial year. The increase in revenue was primarily due to our acquisition of Saloni and the full-year effect of our prior year acquisitions of Keraben and Serra. During the 2019 financial year, our revenue increased by 2.0% on a like-for-like basis, which was primarily attributable to strong revenue growth in our UK & Europe—Soft Flooring segment, partially offset by a decline in revenue generated by our Australia segment and a slight decline in our UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles segment. Our revenue from our UK & Europe—Soft Flooring segment increased by 7.3% on a like-for-like basis over this period, which was primarily the result of the successful re-balancing of our soft flooring product portfolio to take into account recent demand for slightly lower-priced products on average. Our revenue from our Australia segment decreased by 6.9% on a like-for-like basis over this period, which was primarily due to the more challenging trading environment and the impact of tighter mortgage lending caps put in place by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority in 2017, which ended in 2019. Our revenue from our UK & Europe—Ceramic Tiles segment decreased slightly by 1.3% on a like-for-like basis over this period, which was primarily due to the impact of a one-off disruption in Serra’s production due to the installation of a new porcelain production line (completed in June 2018) and some pricing pressure on the small amount of products we export to customers outside of the United Kingdom and Continental Europe. 76 ----- _Revenue by operating segment_ The following table sets forth our revenue for the 2018 and 2019 financial years by operating segment. Prior to the 2019 financial year, we presented our soft flooring and hard flooring operating businesses in the United Kingdom and Continental Europe as a single operating segment (‘‘UK & Europe’’). To facilitate comparability of our operating segments, we have re-presented certain financial information presented for the 2018 financial year in the chart below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our primary sources of liquidity for the periods presented have primarily been our loan facility agreements, cash flows from operations, retained earnings and the Existing Notes. The principal financing arrangements that will be in place following the Offering will consist of the Notes, the Revolving Credit Facility and the BGF Loan, as described in the section entitled ‘‘Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements.’’ On the Issue Date, we will use the proceeds of the Offering (i) for general corporate_ purposes which may include, without limitation, the funding of one or more acquisitions and/or the refinancing of certain existing indebtedness of the Issuer, (ii) to complete the Refinancing, including the payment of accrued and unpaid interest and Redemption and Tender Offer premia and (iii) to pay the fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. See ‘‘Use of Proceeds’’ and ‘‘Capitalization.’’ Following the Offering and the application of the proceeds therefrom, our debt service obligations will consist primarily of interest payments on the Notes, interest payments on the Existing Notes, principal and interest payments on amounts drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility, if any, the BGF Loan and any capital lease obligations. As of October 3, 2020, on a _pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions and the Post-Balance Sheet Transactions, we would have had net senior debt on a consolidated basis of £301.7 million (excluding the impact of IFRS 16—Leases). Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operating activities, together with available borrowings will be adequate to meet our anticipated general liquidity needs and debt service obligations, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations to meet these needs or that future debt or equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to 78 ----- fund our liquidity needs, including making payments on the Notes or other debt when due. If our cash flow from operating activities are lower than expected or our capital expenditure requirements exceed our projections, we may be required to seek additional financing, which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. Our ability to arrange financing generally and the cost of our current and future debt obligations depends on numerous factors, including general economic conditions, the availability of credit from banks, other financial institutions, and capital markets, restrictions in instruments governing our debt, and our general financial performance. See ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our _Structure—We will require a significant amount of cash to service our debt and sustain our operations. Our ability to generate or raise sufficient cash depends on many factors beyond our control.’’_
